In @hkporihkpop survey, 48% respondents said they definitely/probably will vote. This figure is usually far from the final turnout. Even though past interest rates to vote in LegCo elections were between 69% and 86%, final turnout was between 35.8% and 58.28%. https://t.co/qjrIWgeBff

No. of registered voters was 4.46m in 2020. The 334k increase from 2019 was likely because people were anticipating  LegCo election (which got postponed). Likely both camps motivated more voters registered.

No. of registered voters was 4.13m in 2019, at the District Council election during mass protests. Turnout was record 71.2%. ~1.68m voted for pro-democracy camp, ~1.24m voted for (broadly) pro-establishment, with 24,220 invalid ballots. It was a landslide win for democrats. https://t.co/0y9XKjAAXu

Finally, let's do worst-case scenario for pro-Beijing camp.

What if the camp failed to get new supporters after 2019, or because the election system is so good now, people are not interested to vote? Let's use 2019 figure: 1.24/4.47m = 27.7% turnout. https://t.co/CA6D8vEMpT

Now this can explain why these weird banners using pro-democracy/pro-protest symbols urging people to vote have popped up across Hong Kong these few days. The HK govt/pro-Beijing camp is really expecting very few pro-democracy voters to vote. https://t.co/lElIBuMr2b

As of September, 88,000 people have applied for the BN(O) visa to move to the UK. This doesn’t mean they have left, but they want to leave. Most would be pro-democracy camp supporters (excluding children). 

& no clear data as to how many have left for Canada/Aus/Taiwan etc. https://t.co/Jhe0URxaBD

I can safely assume most pro-democracy voters won’t suddenly be persuaded into pro-Beijing voters (otherwise no need to change election system, right?). Say 10% = 168k pro-democracy camp voters would vote.

Best best case scenario: 1.748/4.47m = 39% turnout https://t.co/VbGlrdLdQg

Next variable. How many pro-democracy camp voters would vote? @hkporihkpop did an online survey, only 10% of pro-democracy respondents said there was candidate worth of their support. 84% said none. It’s online survey but results were weighted, so decide for yourself if it’s good https://t.co/Zr5J198O9g

Let’s imagine best case scenario for pro-Beijing camp. Let’s say pro-Beijing camp was shocked by the 2019 defeat & managed to get 334k new supporters next year. So the camp may have 1.58m supporters or more. Let’s say they all vote on Sunday. 1.58/4.47m ~= 35%. Again, best case. https://t.co/bO1CTlqvkv

In @hkporihkpop survey, 48% respondents said they definitely/probably will vote. This figure is usually far from the final turnout. Even though past interest rates to vote in LegCo elections were between 69% and 86%, final turnout was between 35.8% and 58.28%. https://t.co/qjrIWgeBff

No. of registered voters was 4.46m in 2020. The 334k increase from 2019 was likely because people were anticipating  LegCo election (which got postponed). Likely both camps motivated more voters registered. 

This year, the election system was “improved”, only got 6k new voters. https://t.co/W5qx5hotSN

No. of registered voters was 4.13m in 2019, at the District Council election during mass protests. Turnout was record 71.2%. ~1.68m voted for pro-democracy camp, ~1.24m voted for (broadly) pro-establishment, with 24,220 invalid ballots. It was a landslide win for democrats. https://t.co/0y9XKjAAXu
